definition: to write a book advancing one's theory (idiom)
aspect particle indicating action in progress
to make known/to show/to prove/to write/book/outstanding
to touch/to come in contact with/to feel/to be affected by/to catch fire/to burn/(coll.) to fall asleep/(after a verb) hitting the mark/succeeding in
abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]
to stand/to set up/to establish/to lay down/to draw up/at once/immediately
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)

sentences.english: Writing books is a form signifying the establishment of a scholar's own theoretical system.
sentences.chinese: 著書立說是學者們形成自己理論體系的一個表現形式。

sentences.english: What's more, wrote books to advocate the western culture.
sentences.chinese: 此外，他還著書立說，積極宣揚西方文化。

sentences.english: Written cultural transmission was mainly writing books.
sentences.chinese: 書面文化的主要傳播方式是著書立說。

definition: the hardships of beginning an undertaking (idiom)
so dedicated as to forget one's meals (idiom)
(old) to instruct the young/to teach a child to read and write/as easy as ABC
to be confused/to be at a loss/Taiwan pr. [fa1 meng2]
"the four classes" of ancient China, i.e. scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants
to run a newspaper/to publish a newspaper
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
